

========
Experiment configuration: python experiments.py --experiment_name run_intermediate_expansion.py --n_trials 10 --mins_timeout 10 --language Dafny --problem_name problem_opt0 --seed 42 --remove_hints True 


Trial  1
TEXT
### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary additions. Then write an evaluator taking an expression and an environment (a function that takes a variable name and returns a number) and returning the number resulting from evaluation. Then write an optimizer taking an expression and returning an expression with all additions by 0 removed. Then prove that the optimizer preserves the semantics as defined by the evaluation function.

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary additions. Then write an evaluator taking an expression and an environment (a function that takes a variable name and returns a number) and returning the number resulting from evaluation. Then write an optimizer taking an expression and returning an expression with all additions by 0 removed. Then prove that the optimizer preserves the semantics as defined by the evaluation function.



```dafny
// ADT for arithmetic expressions
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(n: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

// Evaluator
function evaluate(e: Expr, env: string -> int): int
{
  match e
  case Const(n) => n
  case Var(name) => env(name)

ex.dfy(12,29): Error: rbrace expected
   |

Then prove that the optimizer preserves the semantics as defined by the evaluation function.



```dafny
// ADT for arithmetic expressions
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(n: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

// Evaluator
function evaluate(e: Expr, env: string -> int): int
{
  match e
  case Const(n) => n
  case Var(name) => env(name)
  case Add(e1, e2) => evaluate(e1, env) + evaluate(e2, env)
}

// Optimizer
function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => e2
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => e1
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}

// Lemma: The optimizer preserves the semantics as defined by the evaluation function
lemma OptimizerSemantics(e: Expr, env: string -> int)
{
  assert evaluate(e, env) == evaluate(optimize(e), env);

datatype Expr = 
  | Const(n: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

  case Const(n) => n
  case Var(name) => env(name)
  case Add(e1, e2) => evaluate(e1, env) + evaluate(e2, env)

  case _ => e

  | Var(name: string)

Then write an evaluator taking an expression and an environment (a function that takes a variable name and returns a number) and returning the number resulting from evaluation. Then write an optimizer taking an expression and returning an expression with all additions by 0 removed. Then prove that the optimizer preserves the semantics as defined by the evaluation function.



```dafny
// ADT for arithmetic expressions
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(n: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

// Evaluator
function evaluate(e: Expr, env: string -> int): int
{
  match e
  case Const(n) => n
  case Var(name) => env(name)
  case Add(e1, e2) => evaluate(e1, env) + evaluate(e2, env)
}

// Optimizer
function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => e2
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => e1
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}

// Lemma: The optimizer preserves the semantics as defined by the evaluation function
lemma OptimizerSemantics(e: Expr, env: string -> int)
{
  assert evaluate(optimize(e), env) == evaluate(e, env);
}
```

ex.dfy(29,9): Error: assertion might not hold
   |
29 |   assert evaluate(optimize(e), env) == evaluate(e, env);
   |          ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^

  case Const(n) => n
  case Var(name) => env(name)
  case Add(e1, e2) => evaluate(e1, env) + evaluate(e2, env)
}

// Optimizer
function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => e2
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => e1
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}

// Lemma: Optimizer preserves semantics
lemma OptimizerPreservesSemantics(e: Expr, env: string -> int)
{
  evaluate(optimize(e), env) == evaluate(e, env)
}

Then write an optimizer taking an expression and returning an expression with all additions by 0 removed. Then prove that the optimizer preserves the semantics as defined by the evaluation function.



```dafny
// ADT for arithmetic expressions
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(n: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

// Evaluator
function evaluate(e: Expr, env: string -> int): int
{
  match e
  case Const(n) => n
  case Var(name) => env(name)
  case Add(e1, e2) => evaluate(e1, env) + evaluate(e2, env)
}

// Optimizer
function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => e2
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => e1
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}

// Lemma: Optimizer preserves semantics
lemma OptimizerPreservesSemantics(e: Expr, env: string -> int)
  ensures evaluate(optimize(e), env) == evaluate(e, env)
{

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary additions. Then write an evaluator taking an expression and an environment (a function that takes a variable name and returns a number) and returning the number resulting from evaluation. Then write an optimizer taking an expression and returning an expression with all additions by 0 removed. Then prove that the optimizer preserves the semantics as defined by the evaluation function.



```dafny
// ADT for arithmetic expressions
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(n: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

// Evaluator
function evaluate(e: Expr, env: string -> int): int
{
  match e
  case Const(n) => n
  case Var(name) => env(name)
  case Add(e1, e2) => evaluate(e1, env) + evaluate(e2, env)
}

// Optimizer
function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => e2
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => e1
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}

// Lemma: Optimizer preserves semantics
lemma OptimizerPreservesSemantics(e: Expr, env: string -> int)
  ensures evaluate(optimize(e), env) == evaluate(e, env)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on e
  // Base cases: Const, Var
  // Inductive case: Add

ex.dfy(32,24): Error: rbrace expected
   |
32 |   // Inductive case: Add
   |                         ^

1 parse errors detected in ex.dfy

None
['  // Inductive case: Add\n']

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary additions. Then write an evaluator taking an expression and an environment (a function that takes a variable name and returns a number) and returning the number resulting from evaluation. Then write an optimizer taking an expression and returning an expression with all additions by 0 removed. Then prove that the optimizer preserves the semantics as defined by the evaluation function.



```dafny
// ADT for arithmetic expressions
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(n: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

// Evaluator
function evaluate(e: Expr, env: string -> int): int
{
  match e
  case Const(n) => n
  case Var(name) => env(name)
  case Add(e1, e2) => evaluate(e1, env) + evaluate(e2, env)
}

// Optimizer
function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => e2
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => e1
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}

// Lemma: Optimizer preserves semantics
lemma OptimizerPreservesSemantics(e: Expr, env: string -> int)
  ensures evaluate(optimize(e), env) == evaluate(e, env)
{
  // Proof by structural induction on e
  // Base cases: Const, Var
  // Inductive case: Add
}

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary additions. Then write an evaluator taking an expression and an environment (a function that takes a variable name and returns a number) and returning the number resulting from evaluation. Then write an optimizer taking an expression and returning an expression with all additions by 0 removed. Then prove that the optimizer preserves the semantics as defined by the evaluation function.



```dafny
// ADT for arithmetic expressions
datatype Expr =
  | Const(value: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)
```

```dafny
// Evaluator function
function evaluate(e: Expr, env: string -> int): int
{
  match e
  case Const(value) => value
  case Var(name) => env(name)
  case Add(e1, e2) => evaluate(e1, env) + evaluate(e2, env)
}
```

datatype Expr =

  case _ => e

  case _ => e

{
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => e2
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => e1
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}
```

  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

  case Const(value) => value
  case Var(name) => env(name)
  case Add(e1, e2) => evaluate(e1, env) + evaluate(e2, env)
}

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary additions. Then write an evaluator taking an expression and an environment (a function that takes a variable name and returns a number) and returning the number resulting from evaluation. Then write an optimizer taking an expression and returning an expression with all additions by 0 removed. Then prove that the optimizer preserves the semantics as defined by the evaluation function.



```dafny
// ADT for arithmetic expressions
datatype Expr =
  | Const(value: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)
```

```dafny
// Evaluator function
function evaluate(e: Expr, env: string -> int): int
{
  match e
  case Const(value) => value
  case Var(name) => env(name)
  case Add(e1, e2) => evaluate(e1, env) + evaluate(e2, env)
}
```

```dafny
// Optimizer function
function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => e2
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => e1
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}
```

```dafny
// Lemma: Optimizer preserves semantics
lemma OptimizerPreservesSemantics(e: Expr, env: string -> int)
  ensures evaluate(optimize(e), env) == evaluate(e, env)
{
  // Base case: Const
  if e == Const(0) {
  } else if e == Const(_) {
  }

  // Base case: Var

   |
38 |   // Base case: Var
   |                    ^

  case Add(Const(0), e2) => e2
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => e1
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}
```

```dafny
// Lemma: Optimizer preserves semantics
lemma OptimizerPreservesSemantics(e: Expr, env: string -> int)
  ensures evaluate(optimize(e), env) == evaluate(e, env)
{
  // Base case: Const
  if e == Const(0) {
  } else if e == Const(_) {
  }

  // Base case: Var
  else if e == Var(_) {
  }

  // Inductive step: Add
  else if e == Add(Const(0), e2) {
    OptimizerPreservesSemantics(e2, env);
  } else if e == Add(e1, Const(0)) {
    OptimizerPreservesSemantics(e1, env);
  } else if e == Add(e1, e2) {
    OptimizerPreservesSemantics(e1, env);
    OptimizerPreservesSemantics(e2, env);
  }
}

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary additions. Then write an evaluator taking an expression and an environment (a function that takes a variable name and returns a number) and returning the number resulting from evaluation. Then write an optimizer taking an expression and returning an expression with all additions by 0 removed. Then prove that the optimizer preserves the semantics as defined by the evaluation function.



```dafny
// ADT for arithmetic expressions
datatype Expr =
  | Const(value: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)
```

```dafny
// Evaluator function
function evaluate(e: Expr, env: string -> int): int
{
  match e
  case Const(value) => value
  case Var(name) => env(name)
  case Add(e1, e2) => evaluate(e1, env) + evaluate(e2, env)
}
```

```dafny
// Optimizer function
function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => e2
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => e1
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}
```

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => e2
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => e1
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}
```

// Lemma: Optimizer preserves semantics

  ensures evaluate(optimize(e), env) == evaluate(e, env)
{

  } else if e == Var(?) {

  case Const(value) => value
  case Var(name) => env(name)
  case Add(e1, e2) => evaluate(e1, env) + evaluate(e2, env)
}
```

```dafny
// Optimizer function
function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => e2
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => e1
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}
```

```dafny
// Lemma: Optimizer preserves semantics
lemma OptimizerPreservesSemantics(e: Expr, env: string -> int)
  ensures evaluate(optimize(e), env) == evaluate(e, env)
{
  // Base case: Const, Var
  if e is Const || e is Var {
  } else if e is Add {
    // Recursive case: Add
    var e1 := (e as Add).e1;
    var e2 := (e as Add).e2;

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary additions. Then write an evaluator taking an expression and an environment (a function that takes a variable name and returns a number) and returning the number resulting from evaluation. Then write an optimizer taking an expression and returning an expression with all additions by 0 removed. Then prove that the optimizer preserves the semantics as defined by the evaluation function.



```dafny
// ADT for arithmetic expressions
datatype Expr =
  | Const(value: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)
```

```dafny
// Evaluator function
function evaluate(e: Expr, env: string -> int): int
{
  match e
  case Const(value) => value
  case Var(name) => env(name)
  case Add(e1, e2) => evaluate(e1, env) + evaluate(e2, env)
}
```

```dafny
// Optimizer function
function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => e2
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => e1
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}
```

```dafny
// Lemma: Optimizer preserves semantics
lemma OptimizerPreservesSemantics(e: Expr, env: string -> int)
{
  let optim_e := optimize(e);

ex.dfy(32,2): Error: missing semicolon at end of statement
   |
32 |   let optim_e := optimize(e);
   |   ^^^

ex.dfy(32,29): Error: rbrace expected
   |
32 |   let optim_e := optimize(e);
   |                              ^

2 parse errors detected in ex.dfy

SCORE
None
['  let optim_e := optimize(e);\n']
TEXT
### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary additions. Then write an evaluator taking an expression and an environment (a function that takes a variable name and returns a number) and returning the number resulting from evaluation. Then write an optimizer taking an expression and returning an expression with all additions by 0 removed. Then prove that the optimizer preserves the semantics as defined by the evaluation function.



```dafny
// ADT for arithmetic expressions
datatype Expr =
  | Const(value: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)
```

```dafny
// Evaluator function
function evaluate(e: Expr, env: string -> int): int
{
  match e
  case Const(value) => value
  case Var(name) => env(name)
  case Add(e1, e2) => evaluate(e1, env) + evaluate(e2, env)
}
```

```dafny
// Optimizer function
function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => e2
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => e1
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}
```

```dafny
// Lemma: Optimizer preserves semantics
lemma OptimizerPreservesSemantics(e: Expr, env: string -> int)
{
  let optim_e := optimize(e);
  evaluate(optim_e, env) == evaluate(e, env)

// ADT for arithmetic expressions
datatype Expr =
  | Const(value: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)
```

```dafny
// Evaluator function
function evaluate(e: Expr, env: string -> int): int
{
  match e
  case Const(value) => value
  case Var(name) => env(name)
  case Add(e1, e2) => evaluate(e1, env) + evaluate(e2, env)

```

```dafny
// Evaluator function
function evaluate(e: Expr, env: string -> int): int
{
  match e
  case Const(value) => value
  case Var(name) => env(name)
  case Add(e1, e2) => evaluate(e1, env) + evaluate(e2, env)
}
```

```dafny
// Optimizer function
function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => e2
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => e1
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}
```

```dafny
// Lemma: The optimizer preserves the semantics as defined by the evaluation function.
lemma OptimizerPreservesSemantics(e: Expr, env: string -> int)
{

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary additions. Then write an evaluator taking an expression and an environment (a function that takes a variable name and returns a number) and returning the number resulting from evaluation. Then write an optimizer taking an expression and returning an expression with all additions by 0 removed. Then prove that the optimizer preserves the semantics as defined by the evaluation function.



```dafny
// ADT for arithmetic expressions
datatype Expr =
  | Const(value: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)
```

```dafny
// Evaluator function
function evaluate(e: Expr, env: string -> int): int
{
  match e
  case Const(value) => value
  case Var(name) => env(name)
  case Add(e1, e2) => evaluate(e1, env) + evaluate(e2, env)
}
```

```dafny
// Optimizer function
function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => e2
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => e1
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}
```

```dafny
// Lemma: The optimizer preserves the semantics
lemma OptimizerSemantics(e: Expr, env: string -> int)
{
  assert evaluate(optimize(e), env) == evaluate(e, env);
}
```

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary additions. Then write an evaluator taking an expression and an environment (a function that takes a variable name and returns a number) and returning the number resulting from evaluation. Then write an optimizer taking an expression and returning an expression with all additions by 0 removed. Then prove that the optimizer preserves the semantics as defined by the evaluation function.



```dafny
// ADT for arithmetic expressions
datatype Expr =
  | Const(value: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)
```

```dafny
// Evaluator function
function evaluate(e: Expr, env: string -> int): int
{
  match e
  case Const(value) => value
  case Var(name) => env(name)
  case Add(e1, e2) => evaluate(e1, env) + evaluate(e2, env)
}
```

```dafny
// Optimizer function
function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => e2
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => e1
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}
```

```dafny
// Lemma to prove that the optimizer preserves the semantics
lemma OptimizerPreservesSemantics(e: Expr, env: string -> int)
  ensures evaluate(optimize(e), env) == evaluate(e, env)
{
  // Base case for recursion: when e is a constant or a variable
  if e == Const(0) || e == Var(?)
  {
  }
  else if e == Add(Const(0), ?) || e == Add(?, Const(0))
  {

   |    ^

  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => e2
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => e1
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}
```

  case Const(value) => value
  case Var(name) => env(name)
  case Add(e1, e2) => evaluate(e1, env) + evaluate(e2, env)
}
```

```dafny
// Optimizer function
function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => e2
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => e1
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}
```

  // Base case: If e is a constant or a variable, the lemma is trivially true

{

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary additions. Then write an evaluator taking an expression and an environment (a function that takes a variable name and returns a number) and returning the number resulting from evaluation. Then write an optimizer taking an expression and returning an expression with all additions by 0 removed. Then prove that the optimizer preserves the semantics as defined by the evaluation function.



```dafny
// ADT for arithmetic expressions
datatype Expr =
  | Const(value: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)
```

```dafny
// Evaluator function
function evaluate(e: Expr, env: string -> int): int
{
  match e
  case Const(value) => value
  case Var(name) => env(name)
  case Add(e1, e2) => evaluate(e1, env) + evaluate(e2, env)
}
```

```dafny
// Optimizer function
function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => e2
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => e1
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}
```

```dafny
// Lemma to prove that the optimizer preserves the semantics
lemma OptimizerPreservesSemantics(e: Expr, env: string -> int)
{
  assert evaluate(optimize(e), env) == evaluate(e, env);
}
``` using System;

ex.dfy(32,9): Error: assertion might not hold
   |
32 |   assert evaluate(optimize(e), env) == evaluate(e, env);
   |          ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^

  match e
  case Const(value) => value
  case Var(name) => env(name)
  case Add(e1, e2) => evaluate(e1, env) + evaluate(e2, env)
}
```

```dafny
// Optimizer function
function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => e2
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => e1
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}
```

```dafny
// Lemma that optimizer preserves semantics
lemma OptimizerSemantics(e: Expr, env: string -> int)
  ensures evaluate(optimize(e), env) == evaluate(e, env)

```dafny
// ADT for arithmetic expressions
datatype Expr =
  | Const(value: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

{

  case Const(value) => value
  case Var(name) => env(name)
  case Add(e1, e2) => evaluate(e1, env) + evaluate(e2, env)
}

{

  case Add(Const(0), e2) => e2
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => e1
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}

  ensures evaluate(optimize(e), env) == evaluate(e, env)
{

  }

```dafny
// ADT for arithmetic expressions
datatype Expr =
  | Const(value: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)
```

```dafny
// Evaluator function
function evaluate(e: Expr, env: string -> int): int
{
  match e
  case Const(value) => value
  case Var(name) => env(name)
  case Add(e1, e2) => evaluate(e1, env) + evaluate(e2, env)

```dafny
// Optimizer function
function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => e2
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => e1
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}

```dafny
// Lemma that optimizer preserves semantics
lemma OptimizerSemantics(e: Expr, env: string -> int)
  ensures evaluate(optimize(e), env) == evaluate(e, env)
{
  if e == Const(_) || e == Var(_)
  {
    // Base case: if e is a constant or a variable, then e and optimize(e) are the same
  }
  else if e == Add(Const(0), e2) || e == Add(e1, Const(0))
  {
    // Base case: if e is an addition by 0, then optimize(e) is the other operand
    // In this case, evaluate(optimize(e), env) == evaluate(e2, env) == evaluate(e, env)
  }
  else
  {
    // Recursive case: if e is an addition of two expressions, then optimize each subexpression
    // Then, by the inductive hypothesis, evaluate(optimize(e1), env) == evaluate(e1, env) and
    // evaluate(optimize(e2), env) == evaluate(e2, env). Therefore,

```dafny
// ADT for arithmetic expressions
datatype Expr =
  | Const(value: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)
```

```dafny
// Evaluator function
function evaluate(e: Expr, env: string -> int): int
{
  match e
  case Const(value) => value
  case Var(name) => env(name)
  case Add(e1, e2) => evaluate(e1, env) + evaluate(e2, env)
}
```

```dafny
// Optimizer function
function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => e2
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => e1
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}

```dafny
// Lemma that optimizer preserves semantics
lemma OptimizerSemantics(e: Expr, env: string -> int)
  ensures evaluate(optimize(e), env) == evaluate(e, env)
{
  if e == Const(_) || e == Var(_)
  {
    // Base case: if e is a constant or a variable, then e and optimize(e) are the same
  }
  else if e == Add(Const(0), e2) || e == Add(e1, Const(0))
  {
    // Base case: if e is an addition by 0, then optimize(e) is the other operand
    // In this case, evaluate(optimize(e), env) == evaluate(e2, env) == evaluate(e, env)
  }
  else
  {
    // Recursive case: if e is an addition of two expressions, then optimize each subexpression
    // Then, by the inductive hypothesis, evaluate(optimize(e1), env) == evaluate(e1, env) and
    // evaluate(optimize(e2), env) == evaluate(e2, env). Therefore,
    // evaluate(optimize(e), env) == evaluate(Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2)), env)

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary additions. Then write an evaluator taking an expression and an environment (a function that takes a variable name and returns a number) and returning the number resulting from evaluation. Then write an optimizer taking an expression and returning an expression with all additions by 0 removed. Then prove that the optimizer preserves the semantics as defined by the evaluation function.



```dafny
// ADT for arithmetic expressions
datatype Expr =
  | Const(value: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)
```

```dafny
// Evaluator function
function evaluate(e: Expr, env: string -> int): int
{
  match e
  case Const(value) => value
  case Var(name) => env(name)
  case Add(e1, e2) => evaluate(e1, env) + evaluate(e2, env)
}
```

```dafny
// Optimizer function
function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => e2
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => e1
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}
```

```dafny
// Lemma that optimizer preserves semantics
lemma OptimizerSemantics(e: Expr, env: string -> int)
  ensures evaluate(optimize(e), env) == evaluate(e, env)
{
  if e == Const(_) || e == Var(_)
  {
    // Base case: if e is a constant or a variable, then e and optimize(e) are the same
  }
  else if e == Add(Const(0), e2) || e == Add(e1, Const(0))
  {
    // Base case: if e is an addition by 0, then optimize(e) is the other operand
    // In this case, evaluate(optimize(e), env) == evaluate(e2, env) == evaluate(e, env)
  }
  else
  {
    // Recursive case: if e is an addition of two expressions, then optimize each subexpression
    // Then, by the inductive hypothesis, evaluate(optimize(e1), env) == evaluate(e1, env) and
    // evaluate(optimize(e2), env) == evaluate(e2, env). Therefore,
    // evaluate(optimize(e), env) == evaluate(Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2)), env)
    // == evaluate(Add(e1, e2), env) == evaluate(e, env).

   |
48 |     // == evaluate(Add(e1, e2), env) == evaluate(e, env).
   |                                                          ^

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary additions. Then write an evaluator taking an expression and an environment (a function that takes a variable name and returns a number) and returning the number resulting from evaluation. Then write an optimizer taking an expression and returning an expression with all additions by 0 removed. Then prove that the optimizer preserves the semantics as defined by the evaluation function.



```dafny
// ADT for arithmetic expressions
datatype Expr =
  | Const(value: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)
```

```dafny
// Evaluator function
function evaluate(e: Expr, env: string -> int): int
{
  match e
  case Const(value) => value
  case Var(name) => env(name)
  case Add(e1, e2) => evaluate(e1, env) + evaluate(e2, env)
}
```

```dafny
// Optimizer function
function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => e2
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => e1
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}
```

```dafny
// Lemma that optimizer preserves semantics
lemma OptimizerSemantics(e: Expr, env: string -> int)
  ensures evaluate(optimize(e), env) == evaluate(e, env)
{
  if e == Const(_) || e == Var(_)
  {
    // Base case: if e is a constant or a variable, then e and optimize(e) are the same
  }
  else if e == Add(Const(0), e2) || e == Add(e1, Const(0))
  {
    // Base case: if e is an addition by 0, then optimize(e) is the other operand
    // In this case, evaluate(optimize(e), env) == evaluate(e2, env) == evaluate(e, env)
  }
  else
  {
    // Recursive case: if e is an addition of two expressions, then optimize each subexpression
    // Then, by the inductive hypothesis, evaluate(optimize(e1), env) == evaluate(e1, env) and
    // evaluate(optimize(e2), env) == evaluate(e2, env). Therefore,
    // evaluate(optimize(e), env) == evaluate(Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2)), env)
    // == evaluate(Add(e1, e2), env) == evaluate(e, env).
    optimize(e) := Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2));

ex.dfy(49,51): Error: rbrace expected
   |
49 |     optimize(e) := Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2));
   |                                                    ^

1 parse errors detected in ex.dfy

SCORE
None
['    optimize(e) := Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2));\n']
TEXT

// Lemma that optimizer preserves semantics

  ensures evaluate(optimize(e), env) == evaluate(e, env)
{
  if e == Const(_) || e == Var(_)
  {
    // Base case: if e is a constant or a variable, then e and optimize(e) are the same
  }
  else if e == Add(Const(0), e2) || e == Add(e1, Const(0))
  {
    // Base case: if e is an addition by 0, then optimize(e) is the other operand
    // In this case, evaluate(optimize(e), env) == evaluate(e2, env) == evaluate(e, env)

    // Then, by the inductive hypothesis, evaluate(optimize(e1), env) == evaluate(e1, env) and
    // evaluate(optimize(e2), env) == evaluate(e2, env). Therefore,
    // evaluate(optimize(e), env) == evaluate(Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2)), env)
    // == evaluate(Add(e1, e2), env) == evaluate(e, env).
    optimize(e) := Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2));
    OptimizerSemantics(e1, env);

```dafny
// Lemma that optimizer preserves semantics

  ensures evaluate(optimize(e), env) == evaluate(e, env)
{
  if e == Const(_) || e == Var(_)
  {
    // Base case: if e is a constant or a variable, then e and optimize(e) are the same
  }
  else if e == Add(Const(0), e2) || e == Add(e1, Const(0))
  {
    // Base case: if e is an addition by 0, then optimize(e) is the other operand
    // In this case, evaluate(optimize(e), env) == evaluate(e2, env) == evaluate(e, env)

    // == evaluate(Add(e1, e2), env) == evaluate(e, env).

  ensures evaluate(optimize(e), env) == evaluate(e, env)
{
  if e == Const(_) || e == Var(_)
  {
    // Base case: if e is a constant or a variable, then e and optimize(e) are the same
  }
  else if e == Add(Const(0), e2) || e == Add(e1, Const(0))

    // In this case, evaluate(optimize(e), env) == evaluate(e2, env) == evaluate(e, env)

// ADT for arithmetic expressions

  | Const(value: int)
  | Var(name: string)

```

```dafny
// Evaluator function

{
  match e
  case Const(value) => value
  case Var(name) => env(name)
  case Add(e1, e2) => evaluate(e1, env) + evaluate(e2, env)

```dafny
// Optimizer function

{
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => e2
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => e1

```dafny
// Lemma that optimizer preserves semantics
lemma OptimizerSemantics(e: Expr, env: string -> int)
  ensures evaluate(optimize(e), env) == evaluate(e, env)
{
  if e == Const(_) || e == Var(_)
  {
    // Base case: if e is a constant or a variable, then e and optimize(e) are the same
  }
  else if e == Add(Const(0), e2) || e == Add(e1, Const(0))
  {
    // Base case: if e is an addition by 0, then optimize(e) is the other operand
    // In this case, evaluate(optimize(e), env) == evaluate(e2, env) == evaluate(e, env)
  }
  else

    // Then, by the inductive hypothesis, evaluate(optimize(e1), env) == evaluate(e1, env) and
    // evaluate(optimize(e2), env) == evaluate(e2, env). Therefore,
    // evaluate(optimize(e), env) == evaluate(Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2)), env)
    // == evaluate(Add(e1, e2), env) == evaluate(e, env).
    optimize(e) := Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2));
    OptimizerSemantics(e1, env);
    OptimizerSemantics(e2, env);
  }

Then write an evaluator taking an expression and an environment (a function that takes a variable name and returns a number) and returning the number resulting from evaluation. Then write an optimizer taking an expression and returning an expression with all additions by 0 removed. ```dafny
// ADT for arithmetic expressions
datatype Expr =
  | Const(value: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)
```

```dafny
// Evaluator function
function evaluate(e: Expr, env: string -> int): int
{
  match e
  case Const(value) => value
  case Var(name) => env(name)
  case Add(e1, e2) => evaluate(e1, env) + evaluate(e2, env)
}
```

// Optimizer function

{

  case Add(Const(0), e2) => e2
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => e1
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary additions. Then write an evaluator taking an expression and an environment (a function that takes a variable name and returns a number) and returning the number resulting from evaluation. Then write an optimizer taking an expression and returning an expression with all additions by 0 removed. Then prove that the optimizer preserves the semantics as defined by the evaluation function.



```dafny
// ADT for arithmetic expressions
datatype Expr =
  | Const(value: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)
```

```dafny
// Evaluator function
function evaluate(e: Expr, env: string -> int): int
{
  match e
  case Const(value) => value
  case Var(name) => env(name)
  case Add(e1, e2) => evaluate(e1, env) + evaluate(e2, env)
}
```

```dafny
// Optimizer function
function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => e2
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => e1
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}
```

```dafny
// Lemma that optimizer preserves semantics
lemma OptimizerSemantics(e: Expr, env: string -> int)
  ensures evaluate(optimize(e), env) == evaluate(e, env)
{
  // ...
}
```

SCORE
1.0
['```\n']
CHOSEN SOLUTION
### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary additions. Then write an evaluator taking an expression and an environment (a function that takes a variable name and returns a number) and returning the number resulting from evaluation. Then write an optimizer taking an expression and returning an expression with all additions by 0 removed. Then prove that the optimizer preserves the semantics as defined by the evaluation function.



```dafny
// ADT for arithmetic expressions
datatype Expr =
  | Const(value: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)
```

```dafny
// Evaluator function
function evaluate(e: Expr, env: string -> int): int
{
  match e
  case Const(value) => value
  case Var(name) => env(name)
  case Add(e1, e2) => evaluate(e1, env) + evaluate(e2, env)
}
```

```dafny
// Optimizer function
function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => e2
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => e1
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}
```

```dafny
// Lemma that optimizer preserves semantics
lemma OptimizerSemantics(e: Expr, env: string -> int)
  ensures evaluate(optimize(e), env) == evaluate(e, env)
{
  // ...
}
```

```dafny
// Evaluator
function evaluate(e: Expr, env: string -> int): int
{
    match e
    case Const(val) => val
    case Var(name) => env(name)
    case Add(e1, e2) => evaluate(e1, env) + evaluate(e2, env)
}
```

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary additions. Then write an evaluator taking an expression and an environment (a function that takes a variable name and returns a number) and returning the number resulting from evaluation. Then write an optimizer taking an expression and returning an expression with all additions by 0 removed. Then prove that the optimizer preserves the semantics as defined by the evaluation function.



```dafny
// ADT for arithmetic expressions
datatype Expr = Const(val: int)
             | Var(name: string)
             | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)
```

```dafny
// Evaluator
function evaluate(e: Expr, env: string -> int): int
{
    match e
    case Const(val) => val
    case Var(name) => env(name)
    case Add(e1, e2) => evaluate(e1, env) + evaluate(e2, env)
}
```

```dafny
// Optimizer
function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
    match e
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => e2
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => e1
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
}
```

```dafny
// Lemma to prove that the optimizer preserves the semantics
lemma OptimizerSemantics(e: Expr, env: string -> int)
    ensures evaluate(optimize(e), env) == evaluate(e, env)
{

ex.dfy(31,1): Error: rbrace expected
   |
31 | {
   |  ^

1 parse errors detected in ex.dfy

SCORE
None
['{\n']
TEXT

datatype Expr = Const(val: int)

    case _ => e

    }

    else if e is Add {

Then prove that the optimizer preserves the semantics as defined by the evaluation function.



```dafny
// ADT for arithmetic expressions
datatype Expr = Const(val: int)
             | Var(name: string)
             | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)
```

```dafny
// Evaluator
function evaluate(e: Expr, env: string -> int): int
{
    match e
    case Const(val) => val
    case Var(name) => env(name)
    case Add(e1, e2) => evaluate(e1, env) + evaluate(e2, env)
}
```

```dafny
// Optimizer
function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
    match e
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => e2
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => e1
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
}
```

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary additions. Then write an evaluator taking an expression and an environment (a function that takes a variable name and returns a number) and returning the number resulting from evaluation. Then write an optimizer taking an expression and returning an expression with all additions by 0 removed. Then prove that the optimizer preserves the semantics as defined by the evaluation function.



```dafny
// ADT for arithmetic expressions
datatype Expr = Const(val: int)
             | Var(name: string)
             | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)
```

```dafny
// Evaluator
function evaluate(e: Expr, env: string -> int): int
{
    match e
    case Const(val) => val
    case Var(name) => env(name)
    case Add(e1, e2) => evaluate(e1, env) + evaluate(e2, env)
}
```

```dafny
// Optimizer
function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
    match e
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => e2
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => e1
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
}
```

```dafny
// Lemma to prove that the optimizer preserves the semantics
lemma OptimizerPreservesSemantics(e: Expr, env: string -> int)
{
    assert evaluate(optimize(e), env) == evaluate(e, env);
}

   |            ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^

             | Var(name: string)

{

    case Const(val) => val
    case Var(name) => env(name)
    case Add(e1, e2) => evaluate(e1, env) + evaluate(e2, env)

    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
}

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary additions. Then write an evaluator taking an expression and an environment (a function that takes a variable name and returns a number) and returning the number resulting from evaluation. Then write an optimizer taking an expression and returning an expression with all additions by 0 removed. Then prove that the optimizer preserves the semantics as defined by the evaluation function.



```dafny
// ADT for arithmetic expressions
datatype Expr = Const(val: int)
             | Var(name: string)
             | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)
```

```dafny
// Evaluator
function evaluate(e: Expr, env: string -> int): int
{
    match e
    case Const(val) => val
    case Var(name) => env(name)
    case Add(e1, e2) => evaluate(e1, env) + evaluate(e2, env)
}
```

```dafny
// Optimizer
function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
    match e
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => e2
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => e1
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
}
```

```dafny
// Lemma: Optimizer preserves semantics
lemma OptimizerSemantics(e: Expr, env: string -> int)
    ensures evaluate(optimize(e), env) == evaluate(e, env)
{
    // Base case: if e is a constant or a variable, the lemma is trivially true
    if e is Const || e is Var {
    }
    else 
    {
        // Inductive step: if e is an addition, we need to show that the optimized version of e1 and e2 also have their semantics preserved
        assert e is Add;
        var e1 := e.e1;
        var e2 := e.e2;
        var e1_opt := optimize(e1);
        var e2_opt := optimize(e2);
        lemma OptimizerSemantics(e1, env);
        lemma OptimizerSemantics(e2, env);

Then write an evaluator taking an expression and an environment (a function that takes a variable name and returns a number) and returning the number resulting from evaluation. Then write an optimizer taking an expression and returning an expression with all additions by 0 removed. Then prove that the optimizer preserves the semantics as defined by the evaluation function.



```dafny
// ADT for arithmetic expressions
datatype Expr = Const(val: int)
             | Var(name: string)
             | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)
```

```dafny
// Evaluator
function evaluate(e: Expr, env: string -> int): int
{
    match e
    case Const(val) => val
    case Var(name) => env(name)
    case Add(e1, e2) => evaluate(e1, env) + evaluate(e2, env)
}
```

```dafny
// Optimizer
function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
    match e
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => e2
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => e1
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
}
```

```dafny
// Lemma: Optimizer preserves semantics
lemma OptimizerSemantics(e: Expr, env: string -> int)
    ensures evaluate(optimize(e), env) == evaluate(e, env)
{
    if e == Const(0) || e == Var(_) {
        // Base case: If e is a constant or a variable, then the optimization doesn't change anything
    } else {
        // Inductive case: If e is an addition, then we recursively prove the lemma for its operands
        assert e == Add(?e1, ?e2);

   |                                   ^

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary additions. Then write an evaluator taking an expression and an environment (a function that takes a variable name and returns a number) and returning the number resulting from evaluation. Then write an optimizer taking an expression and returning an expression with all additions by 0 removed. Then prove that the optimizer preserves the semantics as defined by the evaluation function.



```dafny
// ADT for arithmetic expressions
datatype Expr = Const(val: int)
             | Var(name: string)
             | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)
```

```dafny
// Evaluator
function evaluate(e: Expr, env: string -> int): int
{
    match e
    case Const(val) => val
    case Var(name) => env(name)
    case Add(e1, e2) => evaluate(e1, env) + evaluate(e2, env)
}
```

```dafny
// Optimizer
function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
    match e
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => e2
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => e1
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
}
```

```dafny
// Lemma: The optimizer preserves the semantics as defined by the evaluation function
lemma OptimizerPreservesSemantics(e: Expr, env: string -> int)
{
    assert evaluate(optimize(e), env) == evaluate(e, env);

ex.dfy(31,58): Error: rbrace expected
   |
31 |     assert evaluate(optimize(e), env) == evaluate(e, env);
   |                                                           ^

    case Add(Const(0), e2) => e2
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => e1
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
}
```

{

Then write an evaluator taking an expression and an environment (a function that takes a variable name and returns a number) and returning the number resulting from evaluation. Then write an optimizer taking an expression and returning an expression with all additions by 0 removed. Then prove that the optimizer preserves the semantics as defined by the evaluation function.



```dafny
// ADT for arithmetic expressions
datatype Expr = Const(val: int)
             | Var(name: string)
             | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)
```

```dafny
// Evaluator
function evaluate(e: Expr, env: string -> int): int
{
    match e
    case Const(val) => val
    case Var(name) => env(name)
    case Add(e1, e2) => evaluate(e1, env) + evaluate(e2, env)
}
```

```dafny
// Optimizer
function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
    match e
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => e2
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => e1
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
}
```

```dafny
// Lemma: Optimizer preserves semantics
lemma OptimizerPreservesSemantics(e: Expr, env: string -> int)
{

Then write an optimizer taking an expression and returning an expression with all additions by 0 removed. Then prove that the optimizer preserves the semantics as defined by the evaluation function.



```dafny
// ADT for arithmetic expressions
datatype Expr = Const(val: int)
             | Var(name: string)
             | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)
```

```dafny
// Evaluator
function evaluate(e: Expr, env: string -> int): int
{
    match e
    case Const(val) => val
    case Var(name) => env(name)
    case Add(e1, e2) => evaluate(e1, env) + evaluate(e2, env)
}
```

```dafny
// Optimizer
function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
    match e
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => e2
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => e1
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
}
```

```dafny
// Lemma: The optimizer preserves the semantics as defined by the evaluation function
lemma OptimizerSemantics(e: Expr, env: string -> int)
{
    assert evaluate(optimize(e), env) == evaluate(e, env);
}

```dafny
// Lemma: Optimizer preserves semantics
lemma OptimizerPreservesSemantics(e: Expr, env: string -> int)
    ensures evaluate(optimize(e), env) == evaluate(e, env)
{
    // Base case: if e is a constant, variable, or addition where one of the subexpressions is 0
    if e == Const(0) || e == Var(_) || (e == Add(Const(0), _) || e == Add(_, Const(0))) {

        // so the evaluation results are the same before and after optimization.

```dafny
// Lemma: Optimizer preserves semantics
lemma OptimizerPreservesSemantics(e: Expr, env: string -> int)
    ensures evaluate(optimize(e), env) == evaluate(e, env)
{
    // Base case: if e is a constant, variable, or addition where one of the subexpressions is 0
    if e == Const(0) || e == Var(_) || (e == Add(Const(0), _) || e == Add(_, Const(0))) {

datatype Expr = Const(val: int)
             | Var(name: string)
             | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)
```

```dafny
// Evaluator
function evaluate(e: Expr, env: string -> int): int
{
    match e
    case Const(val) => val
    case Var(name) => env(name)
    case Add(e1, e2) => evaluate(e1, env) + evaluate(e2, env)
}
```

```dafny
// Optimizer
function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
    match e
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => e2
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => e1
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
}
```

```dafny
// Lemma: Optimizer preserves semantics
lemma OptimizerPreservesSemantics(e: Expr, env: string -> int)
    ensures evaluate(optimize(e), env) == evaluate(e, env)
{
    // Base case: if e is a constant, variable, or addition where one of the subexpressions is 0
    if e == Const(0) || e == Var(_) || (e == Add(Const(0), _) || e == Add(_, Const(0))) {
        // In these cases, the optimizer does not change the expression,
        // so the evaluation results are the same before and after optimization.
    }
    // Inductive case: if e is an addition of two non-constant, non-variable subexpressions
    else if e == Add(e1, e2) && e1 != Const(0) && e1 != Var(_) && e2 != Const(0) && e2 != Var(_) {
        // Recursive call on subexpressions
        OptimizerPreservesSemantics(e1, env);
        OptimizerPreservesSemantics(e2, env);
    }

ex.dfy(42,5): Error: rbrace expected
   |
42 |     }
   |      ^

1 parse errors detected in ex.dfy

SCORE
None
['    }\n']

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary additions. Then write an evaluator taking an expression and an environment (a function that takes a variable name and returns a number) and returning the number resulting from evaluation. Then write an optimizer taking an expression and returning an expression with all additions by 0 removed. Then prove that the optimizer preserves the semantics as defined by the evaluation function.



```dafny
// ADT for arithmetic expressions
datatype Expr = Const(val: int)
             | Var(name: string)
             | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)
```

```dafny
// Evaluator
function evaluate(e: Expr, env: string -> int): int
{
    match e
    case Const(val) => val
    case Var(name) => env(name)
    case Add(e1, e2) => evaluate(e1, env) + evaluate(e2, env)
}
```

```dafny
// Optimizer
function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
    match e
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => e2
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => e1
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
}
```

```dafny
// Lemma: Optimizer preserves semantics
lemma OptimizerPreservesSemantics(e: Expr, env: string -> int)
    ensures evaluate(optimize(e), env) == evaluate(e, env)
{
    // Base case: Const
    if e is Const {}
    else if e is Var {}
    else if e is Add {
        // Case: e1 is Add
        if e.e1 is Add {
            assert e.e1 == optimize(e.e1);
            OptimizerPreservesSemantics(e.e1, env);
        }
        // Case: e2 is Add
        if e.e2 is Add {
            assert e.e2 == optimize(e.e2);

   |                                           ^

             | Var(name: string)
             | Add(lhs: Expr, rhs: Expr)

{

    case Var(name): return env(name)
    case Add(lhs, rhs): return Evaluate(lhs, env) + Evaluate(rhs, env)

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary additions. Then write an evaluator taking an expression and an environment (a function that takes a variable name and returns a number) and returning the number resulting from evaluation. Then write an optimizer taking an expression and returning an expression with all additions by 0 removed. Then prove that the optimizer preserves the semantics as defined by the evaluation function.



```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(val: int)
             | Var(name: string)
             | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

function Evaluate(e: Expr, env: string -> int): int
{
  match e
  case Const(val): return val;
  case Var(name): return env(name);
  case Add(e1, e2): return Evaluate(e1, env) + Evaluate(e2, env);

ex.dfy(8,17): Error: darrow expected
  |
8 |   case Const(val): return val;
  |                  ^

1 parse errors detected in ex.dfy

```dafny

             | Var(name: string)
             | Add(left: Expr, right: Expr)

        case Add(left, Const(0)) => Optimize(left)
        case Add(left, right) => Add(Optimize(left), Optimize(right))
        case _ => e

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary additions. Then write an evaluator taking an expression and an environment (a function that takes a variable name and returns a number) and returning the number resulting from evaluation. Then write an optimizer taking an expression and returning an expression with all additions by 0 removed. Then prove that the optimizer preserves the semantics as defined by the evaluation function.



```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(val: int)
             | Var(name: string)
             | Add(left: Expr, right: Expr)

function Eval(e: Expr, env: string -> int): int {
    match e
        case Const(val) => val
        case Var(name) => env(name)
        case Add(left, right) => Eval(left, env) + Eval(right, env)
}

function Optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
    match e
        case Add(Const(0), right) => Optimize(right)
        case Add(left, Const(0)) => Optimize(left)
        case Add(left, right) => Add(Optimize(left), Optimize(right))
        case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizePreservesSemantics(e: Expr, env: string -> int)
    ensures Eval(Optimize(e), env) == Eval(e, env)
{

ex.dfy(22,1): Error: rbrace expected
   |
22 | {
   |  ^

1 parse errors detected in ex.dfy

['{\n']

CHOSEN SOLUTION
### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary additions. Then write an evaluator taking an expression and an environment (a function that takes a variable name and returns a number) and returning the number resulting from evaluation. Then write an optimizer taking an expression and returning an expression with all additions by 0 removed. Then prove that the optimizer preserves the semantics as defined by the evaluation function.



```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(val: int)
             | Var(name: string)
             | Add(left: Expr, right: Expr)

function Eval(e: Expr, env: string -> int): int {
    match e
        case Const(val) => val
        case Var(name) => env(name)
        case Add(left, right) => Eval(left, env) + Eval(right, env)
}

function Optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
    match e
        case Add(Const(0), right) => Optimize(right)
        case Add(left, Const(0)) => Optimize(left)
        case Add(left, right) => Add(Optimize(left), Optimize(right))
        case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizePreservesSemantics(e: Expr, env: string -> int)
    ensures Eval(Optimize(e), env) == Eval(e, env)
{
    // Here's a sketch of how you might prove this lemma.
    // You would need to inductively prove that Optimize preserves the semantics
    // for each type of expression.
}

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary additions. Then write an evaluator taking an expression and an environment (a function that takes a variable name and returns a number) and returning the number resulting from evaluation. Then write an optimizer taking an expression and returning an expression with all additions by 0 removed. Then prove that the optimizer preserves the semantics as defined by the evaluation function.



```dafny
// ADT for arithmetic expressions
datatype Expr = Const(val: int)
              | Var(name: string)
              | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

// Evaluator
function eval(e: Expr, env: string -> int): int
{
    match e
    case Const(val): val
    case Var(name): env(name)
    case Add(e1, e2): eval(e1, env) + eval(e2, env)

```dafny
// ADT for arithmetic expressions
datatype Expr = Const(val: int)
              | Var(name: string)
              | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

// Evaluator

{
  match e
  case Const(val) => val
  case Var(name) => env(name)
  case Add(e1, e2) => eval(e1, env) + eval(e2, env)

{
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))

// ADT for arithmetic expressions
datatype Expr = Const(val: int)
              | Var(name: string)
              | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

{
  match e
  case Const(val) => val
  case Var(name) => env(name)
  case Add(e1, e2) => eval(e1, env) + eval(e2, env)
}

// Optimizer
function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}

```dafny
// ADT for arithmetic expressions
datatype Expr = Const(val: int)
              | Var(name: string)
              | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

// Evaluator
function eval(e: Expr, env: string -> int): int
{
  match e
  case Const(val) => val
  case Var(name) => env(name)
  case Add(e1, e2) => eval(e1, env) + eval(e2, env)
}

// Optimizer
function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}

// Lemma to prove that the optimizer preserves semantics

{

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary additions. Then write an evaluator taking an expression and an environment (a function that takes a variable name and returns a number) and returning the number resulting from evaluation. Then write an optimizer taking an expression and returning an expression with all additions by 0 removed. Then prove that the optimizer preserves the semantics as defined by the evaluation function.



```dafny
// ADT for arithmetic expressions
datatype Expr = Const(val: int)
              | Var(name: string)
              | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

// Evaluator
function eval(e: Expr, env: string -> int): int
{
  match e
  case Const(val) => val
  case Var(name) => env(name)
  case Add(e1, e2) => eval(e1, env) + eval(e2, env)
}

// Optimizer
function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}

// Lemma to prove that the optimizer preserves semantics
lemma OptimizerPreservesSemantics(e: Expr, env: string -> int)
{
  assert eval(optimize(e), env) == eval(e, env);
}

```dafny
// ADT for arithmetic expressions
datatype Expr = Const(val: int)
              | Var(name: string)
              | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

// Evaluator
function eval(e: Expr, env: string -> int): int
{
  match e
  case Const(val) => val
  case Var(name) => env(name)
  case Add(e1, e2) => eval(e1, env) + eval(e2, env)
}

// Optimizer

{
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}

// ADT for arithmetic expressions
datatype Expr = Const(val: int)
              | Var(name: string)
              | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

// Evaluator

{

  case Const(val) => val
  case Var(name) => env(name)
  case Add(e1, e2) => eval(e1, env) + eval(e2, env)

  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e

```dafny
// ADT for arithmetic expressions
datatype Expr = Const(val: int)
              | Var(name: string)
              | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

// Evaluator
function eval(e: Expr, env: string -> int): int
{
  match e
  case Const(val) => val
  case Var(name) => env(name)
  case Add(e1, e2) => eval(e1, env) + eval(e2, env)
}

// Optimizer
function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}

// Lemma to prove that the optimizer preserves semantics
lemma OptimizerPreservesSemantics(e: Expr, env: string -> int)
  requires true
  ensures eval(optimize(e), env) == eval(e, env)
{
  // Base case: e is a constant
  if e is Const {
    assert optimize(e) == e;
    assert eval(optimize(e), env) == eval(e, env);
  }

  // Base case: e is a variable
  else if e is Var {
    assert optimize(e) == e;
    assert eval(optimize(e), env) == eval(e, env);
  }

  // Inductive case: e is an addition
  else if e is Add {
    assert e == Add(?e1, ?e2);
    OptimizerPreservesSemantics(e1, env);
    OptimizerPreservesSemantics(e2, env);
    assert optimize(e) == Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2));

```dafny

              | Var(name: string)
              | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

// Evaluator

{

  case Var(name) => env(name)
  case Add(e1, e2) => eval(e1, env) + eval(e2, env)

{
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}

// Lemma to prove that the optimizer preserves semantics
lemma OptimizerPreservesSemantics(e: Expr, env: string -> int)
  requires true
  ensures eval(optimize(e), env) == eval(e, env)
{
  // Base case: e is a constant
  if e is Const {
    assert optimize(e) == e;
    assert eval(optimize(e), env) == eval(e, env);
  }

  // Base case: e is a variable
  else if e is Var {
    assert optimize(e) == e;
    assert eval(optimize(e), env) == eval(e, env);
  }

  // Inductive case: e is an addition
  else if e is Add {
    assert e == Add(?e1, ?e2);
    OptimizerPreservesSemantics(e1, env);
    OptimizerPreservesSemantics(e2, env);
    assert optimize(e) == Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2));
    assert eval(optimize(e), env) == eval(e, env);

```dafny
// ADT for arithmetic expressions
datatype Expr = Const(val: int)
              | Var(name: string)
              | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

// Evaluator
function eval(e: Expr, env: string -> int): int
{
  match e
  case Const(val) => val
  case Var(name) => env(name)
  case Add(e1, e2) => eval(e1, env) + eval(e2, env)
}

// Optimizer
function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}

  requires true
  ensures eval(optimize(e), env) == eval(e, env)

    assert optimize(e) == e;
    assert eval(optimize(e), env) == eval(e, env);
  }

    assert optimize(e) == e;
    assert eval(optimize(e), env) == eval(e, env);
  }

  // Inductive case: e is an addition

    assert e == Add(?e1, ?e2);
    OptimizerPreservesSemantics(e1, env);
    OptimizerPreservesSemantics(e2, env);
    assert optimize(e) == Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2));
    assert eval(optimize(e), env) == eval(e, env);

  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}

              | Var(name: string)

{

  case Const(val) => val
  case Var(name) => env(name)
  case Add(e1, e2) => eval(e1, env) + eval(e2, env)

  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))

Then write an evaluator taking an expression and an environment (a function that takes a variable name and returns a number) and returning the number resulting from evaluation. Then write an optimizer taking an expression and returning an expression with all additions by 0 removed. Then prove that the optimizer preserves the semantics as defined by the evaluation function.



```dafny
// ADT for arithmetic expressions
datatype Expr = Const(val: int)
              | Var(name: string)
              | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

// Evaluator
function eval(e: Expr, env: string -> int): int
{
  match e
  case Const(val) => val
  case Var(name) => env(name)
  case Add(e1, e2) => eval(e1, env) + eval(e2, env)
}

// Optimizer
function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}

// Lemma to prove that the optimizer preserves semantics
lemma OptimizerPreservesSemantics(e: Expr, env: string -> int)
  requires true
  ensures eval(optimize(e), env) == eval(e, env)
{
  // Base case for recursion: if e is a constant or a variable, the result is trivial.
  if e is Const || e is Var {
  } else {
    // Recursive case for addition: evaluate both sides of the equality and then recursively invoke the lemma.
    assert eval(optimize(e), env) == eval(e, env);
    assert eval(optimize(Add(e.e1, e.e2)), env) == eval(Add(e.e1, e.e2), env);

```dafny
// ADT for arithmetic expressions
datatype Expr = Const(val: int)
              | Var(name: string)
              | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

{

  case Const(val) => val
  case Var(name) => env(name)
  case Add(e1, e2) => eval(e1, env) + eval(e2, env)
}

// Optimizer
function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}

  requires true
  ensures eval(optimize(e), env) == eval(e, env)
{
  // Base case for recursion: if e is a constant or a variable, the result is trivial.
  if e is Const || e is Var {
  } else {

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary additions. Then write an evaluator taking an expression and an environment (a function that takes a variable name and returns a number) and returning the number resulting from evaluation. ```dafny

              | Var(name: string)
              | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

// Evaluator

{
  match e
  case Const(val) => val
  case Var(name) => env(name)
  case Add(e1, e2) => eval(e1, env) + eval(e2, env)
}

// Optimizer

{
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e

             | Var(name: string)

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(val: int)
              | Var(name: string)
              | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

function Eval(e: Expr, env: string -> int): int
{
    match e
    case Const(val) => val
    case Var(name) => env(name)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Eval(e1, env) + Eval(e2, env)

    case Add(Const(0), e2) => Optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => Optimize(e1)

    case _ => true

```dafny

              | Var(name: string)
              | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

{
    match e
    case Const(val) => val
    case Var(name) => env(name)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Eval(e1, env) + Eval(e2, env)

    case Add(Const(0), e2) => Optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => Optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(Optimize(e1), Optimize(e2))

    case Add(Const(0), _) => false
    case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
    case Add(e1, e2) => IsOptimized(e1) && IsOptimized(e2)
    case _ => true

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary additions. Then write an evaluator taking an expression and an environment (a function that takes a variable name and returns a number) and returning the number resulting from evaluation. Then write an optimizer taking an expression and returning an expression with all additions by 0 removed. Then prove that the optimizer preserves the semantics as defined by the evaluation function.



```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(val: int)
              | Var(name: string)
              | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

function Eval(e: Expr, env: string -> int): int
{
    match e
    case Const(val) => val
    case Var(name) => env(name)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Eval(e1, env) + Eval(e2, env)
}

function Optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
    match e
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => Optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => Optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(Optimize(e1), Optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
}

predicate IsOptimized(e: Expr)
{
    match e
    case Add(Const(0), _) => false
    case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
    case Add(e1, e2) => IsOptimized(e1) && IsOptimized(e2)
    case _ => true
}

lemma OptimizerPreservesSemantics(e: Expr, env: string -> int)
    requires IsOptimized(e)
    ensures Eval(e, env) == Eval(Optimize(e), env)
{
    // Proof by structural induction on e.
    if e == Const(_) || e == Var(_) {
        // Base case: Const and Var have no subexpressions to optimize.
    } else if e == Add(_, _) {
        var e1 := e.Add_e1;
        var e2 := e.Add_e2;
        // Recursive case: Optimize subexpressions first.
        OptimizerPreservesSemantics(e1, env);

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary additions. Then write an evaluator taking an expression and an environment (a function that takes a variable name and returns a number) and returning the number resulting from evaluation. Then write an optimizer taking an expression and returning an expression with all additions by 0 removed. Then prove that the optimizer preserves the semantics as defined by the evaluation function.



```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(val: int)
              | Var(name: string)
              | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

function Eval(e: Expr, env: string -> int): int
{
    match e
    case Const(val) => val
    case Var(name) => env(name)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Eval(e1, env) + Eval(e2, env)
}

function Optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
    match e
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => Optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => Optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(Optimize(e1), Optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
}

predicate IsOptimized(e: Expr)
{
    match e
    case Add(Const(0), _) => false
    case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
    case Add(e1, e2) => IsOptimized(e1) && IsOptimized(e2)
    case _ => true
}

lemma OptimizerPreservesSemantics(e: Expr, env: string -> int)
    requires IsOptimized(e)
    ensures Eval(e, env) == Eval(Optimize(e), env)
{
    // Proof by structural induction on e.
    if e == Const(_) || e == Var(_) {
        // Base case: Const and Var have no subexpressions to optimize.
    } else if e == Add(_, _) {
        var e1 := e.Add_e1;
        var e2 := e.Add_e2;
        // Recursive case: Optimize subexpressions first.
        OptimizerPreservesSemantics(e1, env);
        OptimizerPreservesSemantics(e2, env);

ex.dfy(43,45): Error: rbrace expected
   |
43 |         OptimizerPreservesSemantics(e2, env);
   |                                              ^

Then write an optimizer taking an expression and returning an expression with all additions by 0 removed. ```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(val: int)
              | Var(name: string)
              | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

function Eval(e: Expr, env: string -> int): int
{
    match e
    case Const(val) => val
    case Var(name) => env(name)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Eval(e1, env) + Eval(e2, env)

    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => Optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(Optimize(e1), Optimize(e2))
    case _ => e

    match e
    case Add(Const(0), _) => false
    case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
    case Add(e1, e2) => IsOptimized(e1) && IsOptimized(e2)
    case _ => true
}

lemma OptimizerPreservesSemantics(e: Expr, env: string -> int)
    requires IsOptimized(e)
    ensures Eval(e, env) == Eval(Optimize(e), env)

        // Base case: Const and Var have no subexpressions to optimize.
    } else if e == Add(_, _) {

        var e2 := e.Add_e2;
        // Recursive case: Optimize subexpressions first.
        OptimizerPreservesSemantics(e1, env);
        OptimizerPreservesSemantics(e2, env);

    // Then prove the lemma for the current expression.
    assert Eval(e, env) == Eval(Optimize(e), env);

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary additions. Then write an evaluator taking an expression and an environment (a function that takes a variable name and returns a number) and returning the number resulting from evaluation. Then write an optimizer taking an expression and returning an expression with all additions by 0 removed. Then prove that the optimizer preserves the semantics as defined by the evaluation function.



```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(val: int)
              | Var(name: string)
              | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

function Eval(e: Expr, env: string -> int): int
{
    match e
    case Const(val) => val
    case Var(name) => env(name)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Eval(e1, env) + Eval(e2, env)
}

function Optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
    match e
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => Optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => Optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(Optimize(e1), Optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
}

predicate IsOptimized(e: Expr)
{
    match e
    case Add(Const(0), _) => false
    case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
    case Add(e1, e2) => IsOptimized(e1) && IsOptimized(e2)
    case _ => true
}

    requires IsOptimized(e)
    ensures Eval(e, env) == Eval(Optimize(e), env)

    // ...

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary additions. Then write an evaluator taking an expression and an environment (a function that takes a variable name and returns a number) and returning the number resulting from evaluation. Then write an optimizer taking an expression and returning an expression with all additions by 0 removed. Then prove that the optimizer preserves the semantics as defined by the evaluation function.



```dafny
// ADT for arithmetic expressions
datatype Expr =
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

// Evaluator
function eval(e: Expr, env: string -> int): int
  reads env
{
  match e
  case Const(val): return val
  case Var(name): return env(name)
  case Add(e1, e2): return eval(e1, env) + eval(e2, env)

ex.dfy(12,17): Error: darrow expected
   |
12 |   case Const(val): return val
   |                  ^

// Lemma: The optimizer preserves the semantics
lemma OptimizerSemantics(e: Expr, env: string -> int)
  ensures evaluate(optimize(e), env) == evaluate(e, env)

// Evaluator

{

  case Const(val) => val
  case Var(name) => env(name)
  case Add(e1, e2) => evaluate(e1, env) + evaluate(e2, env)
}
```

```dafny
// Optimizer
function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}
```

```dafny
// Lemma: The optimizer preserves the semantics
lemma OptimizerSemantics(e: Expr, env: string -> int)
  ensures evaluate(optimize(e), env) == evaluate(e, env)
{

Then write an evaluator taking an expression and an environment (a function that takes a variable name and returns a number) and returning the number resulting from evaluation. Then write an optimizer taking an expression and returning an expression with all additions by 0 removed. Then prove that the optimizer preserves the semantics as defined by the evaluation function.



```dafny
// ADT for arithmetic expressions
datatype Expr =
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)
```

```dafny
// Evaluator
function evaluate(e: Expr, env: string -> int): int
{
  match e
  case Const(val) => val
  case Var(name) => env(name)
  case Add(e1, e2) => evaluate(e1, env) + evaluate(e2, env)
}
```

```dafny
// Optimizer
function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}
```

```dafny
// Lemma: The optimizer preserves the semantics
lemma OptimizerSemantics(e: Expr, env: string -> int)
  ensures evaluate(optimize(e), env) == evaluate(e, env)
{
  // Base case: If e is a constant or a variable, the lemma holds.
  if e is Const || e is Var {
  } else {
    // Inductive case: If e is an addition, recursively prove the lemma for its operands.
    match e {
      case Add(e1, e2) {
        OptimizerSemantics(e1, env);
        OptimizerSemantics(e2, env);

ex.dfy(38,23): Error: darrow expected
   |
38 |       case Add(e1, e2) {
   |                        ^

ex.dfy(40,36): Error: rbrace expected
   |
40 |         OptimizerSemantics(e2, env);
   |                                     ^

2 parse errors detected in ex.dfy

SCORE
-1.0
['        OptimizerSemantics(e2, env);\n']

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary additions. Then write an evaluator taking an expression and an environment (a function that takes a variable name and returns a number) and returning the number resulting from evaluation. Then write an optimizer taking an expression and returning an expression with all additions by 0 removed. Then prove that the optimizer preserves the semantics as defined by the evaluation function.



```dafny
// ADT for arithmetic expressions
datatype Expr =
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)
```

```dafny
// Evaluator
function evaluate(e: Expr, env: string -> int): int
{
  match e
  case Const(val) => val
  case Var(name) => env(name)
  case Add(e1, e2) => evaluate(e1, env) + evaluate(e2, env)
}
```

```dafny
// Optimizer
function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}
```

```dafny
// Lemma: Optimizer preserves semantics
lemma OptimizerPreservesSemantics(e: Expr, env: string -> int)
{
  assert evaluate(optimize(e), env) == evaluate(e, env);
}
``` package com.github.j5ik2o.akka.persistence.s3.journal

ex.dfy(32,9): Error: assertion might not hold
   |
32 |   assert evaluate(optimize(e), env) == evaluate(e, env);
   |          ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^


Dafny program verifier finished with 2 verified, 1 error

SCORE
-1.0
['``` package com.github.j5ik2o.akka.persistence.s3.journal\n']
['{\n']
['  assert evaluate(optimize(e), env) == evaluate(e, env);\n']
['}\n']
TEXT

// ADT for arithmetic expressions
datatype Expr =
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)
```

```dafny
// Evaluator
function evaluate(e: Expr, env: string -> int): int
{
  match e
  case Const(val) => val
  case Var(name) => env(name)
  case Add(e1, e2) => evaluate(e1, env) + evaluate(e2, env)
}
```

```dafny
// Optimizer
function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}
```

```dafny

  ensures evaluate(optimize(e), env) == evaluate(e, env)
{
  // Base case for recursion: Const and Var
  // For Const, the result is always the same

// Lemma to prove that the optimizer preserves the semantics
lemma OptimizerPreservesSemantics(e: Expr, env: string -> int)
  ensures evaluate(optimize(e), env) == evaluate(e, env)

  // For Var, the result depends on the environment, but the optimizer doesn't change Var,
  // so the result will be the same

    // Recursive call for Add
    OptimizerPreservesSemantics(e1, env);
    OptimizerPreservesSemantics(e2, env);

  ensures evaluate(optimize(e), env) == evaluate(e, env)
